questions.question_text: Which three are true about the default database buffer cache? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Why B?
https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/CNCPT/memory.htm#CNCPT804
I think CFG

CFG

B - wrong 

The fixed SGA is an internal housekeeping area.

For example, the fixed SGA contains:
* General information about the state of the database and the instance, which the background processes need to access
* Information communicated between processes, such as information about locks

Selected Answer: CEG
Answer is CEG

Selected Answer: CEG
a) No. This is not the only algorithm
b) No. It is not fixed.
c) Yes. It can.
d) No. This is not the only algorithm.
e) Yes. This is the default buffer cache and block_size is relevant here.
f) No. These buffers have their own size.
g) Yes. New blocks may have not been written to disk yet.

My answer: CEG

CDE
the rigth ansewr is CDE consider 
A. not lru buffer cache uses touche count
B. SGA maight or migth not be fixed
C.Its buffers can contain data block images for blocks that have a corresponding image in a data file.
D. Buffers containing block images may be selected for reuse based only on a touch count algorithm. 
reuse is base on touche count
E.It can contain block images only for database blocks whose block size is equal to the buffer size.
E is correct
F.keep and recycle cache memory are not sub_allocated from memery allocated to the defulet
 buffer cache the are sub_allocated to buffer_cache(not the defolte one)
 sub_allocated of uffer_cache are 
 
 db_cache_size is the default buffer cache
 db_keep_cache_size is for the KEEP buffer cache
 db_recycle_ cache_size is for the RECYCLE buffer cache
 db_nk_ cache_size
CFG is correct.
So which are correct??

CEG
For F,https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/CNCPT/memory.htm#CNCPT1222 key words: Figure 14-7 Database Buffer Cache

ACF
http://www.pafumi.net/Oracle_Architecture_and_Administration.html

ACG
A correct

choices.F: The keep and recycle cache memory is sub-allocated from memory allocated to the default buffer cache.
choices.C: Its buffers can contain data block images for blocks that have a corresponding image in a data file.
choices.G: Its buffers can contain data block images for blocks that have no corresponding image in a data file.
choices.A: Buffers containing block images may be selected for reuse based only on a Least Recently Used (LRU) algorithm.
choices.E: It can contain block images only for database blocks whose block size is equal to the buffer size.
choices.D: Buffers containing block images may be selected for reuse based only on a touch count algorithm.
choices.B: It is in the fixed area of the SGA.

questions.question_text: Which are three of the input sources for the SQL Tuning Advisor? (Choose three.)

comments.content:
D is true, I have tested and it given this error:
ORA-39034: Table EMP does not exist.

discussion.content: it is not given TABLES=emp exists , so D is true

Selected Answer: D
The use of synonyms as values for the TABLES parameter is not supported. For example, if the regions table in the hr schema had a synonym of regn, then it would not be valid to use TABLES=regn. An error would be returned.
D is true, ref: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SUTIL/GUID-9D052182-6BD8-4167-B528-2E352C9CDBDB.htm#SUTIL866 key words: synonyms

choices.A: It throws an error as the QUERY parameter is not supported on an empty table.
choices.D: It throws an error as Data Pump cannot find a table called TEST.EMP.
choices.B: It throws an error as the table test_employees is empty and CONTENT=data_only is specified.

discussion.content:

Indexes
Materialized views
Materialized view logs
Partitions

questions.question_text: Which two can be recommendations given by SQL Access Advisor? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: A E , C is incorrect as long row is also chained

AE is correct
A row is stored in a database block in the form of a row piece,
Each row piece has a row header and column data

Selected Answer: AE
Answer is AE

A= "Oracle Database stores rows as variable-length records. A row is contained in one or more sections. Each section is called a row piece. Each row piece has a row header and column data."
C would have been correct, if the key word ONLY was not used, as there are other factors which will cause row chaining.

 "Row chaining most often occurs with large rows. Examples include rows that contain a column of data type LONG or LONG RAW , or a row with a huge number of columns. Row chaining in these cases is unavoidable."

-https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/CNCPT/logical.htm#CNCPT1061

C and E correct answers if the number of rows are more than 255 oracle starts to create other row and it chain rows for net time block read. row can be a single block if it has small
 data

AE
For A,https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/CNCPT/logical.htm#CNCPT1046 key words: Row Format

C&E is correct
ref: https://blogs.sap.com/2013/02/17/oracle-unchain-database-and-sql-performance-by-design-row-chaining/
A,B is true

questions.question_text: Which two are true about database table rows? (Choose two.)

choices.B: They are always stored in a single database block.
choices.D: They have a row header only when they are chained across multiple database blocks.
choices.A: They always have a row header.
choices.E: They can be stored in a single database block.
choices.C: They are chained across multiple blocks only when the table has more than 255 columns.
